data.heading: Introduction
data.instructions:
This document describes product or process failures using Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) method.

You can identify potential failure modes, their causes, and effects on the system or stakeholders.

For each identified cause and effect you can assess its risk and determine corrective actions.

For more information see Effective FMEAs by Carl Carlson.

children.heading: Purpose Modified
children.instructions: Identify the product specified in this document.

children.text:
This is an example document describing risks related to development of ReqView version 1.0.

Note: This is an example document, which is not complete.
The main purpose of this document is to provide new ReqView users a working example of a document describing project risks by means of Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) method.

children.heading: Scope
children.instructions: Briefly describe the scope of the product risk analysis.

children.text: This document describes risks related to ReqView version 1.0 functionality specified in [DEMO-NEEDS] document .
This section provides example definitions of probability, severability and detectability taken from Wikipedia.

Severity:

RatingMeaning
1-2No relevant effect on reliability or safety
3-4Very minor, no damage, no injuries, only results in a maintenance action (only noticed by discriminating customers)
5-6Minor, low damage, light injuries (affects very little of the system, noticed by average customer)
7-8Critical (causes a loss of primary function; Loss of all safety Margins, 1 failure away from a catastrophe, severe damage, severe injuries, max 1 possible death )
9-10Catastrophic (product becomes inoperative; the failure may result in complete unsafe operation and possible multiple deaths)
children.instructions: Define rank for severity from 1 (no effect) up to 10 (catastrophic) used further in the document, see example.

children.text:
Probability:

RatingMeaning
1-2Extremely Unlikely (Virtually impossible or No known occurrences on similar products or processes, with many running hours)
3-4Remote (relatively few failures)
5-6Occasional (occasional failures)
7-8Reasonably Possible (repeated failures)
9-10Frequent (failure is almost inevitable)
children.instructions: Define rank for probability from 1 (extremely unlikely) to 10 (inevitable) used further in the document, see example.

children.text:
Detectability:

RatingMeaning
1Certain – fault will be caught on test - e.g. Poka-Yoke
2-3Almost certain
4-5High
6-7Moderate
8-9Low
10Fault is undetected by Operators or Maintainers
children.instructions: Define rank for detection from 1 (almost certain) up to 10 (absolute uncertainly) used further in the document, see example.

data.heading: Risks
data.instructions:
Identify potential failure modes, their causes, and effects on the system or stakeholders. For each identified cause and effect assess its risk and determine corrective actions. For more information see Effective FMEAs by Carl Carlson.

Organize failures by items or process step into sections with the following hierarchy: Function → Failure Mode → Potential Cause → Corrective Action.

Function

  • Type: set to "Function" value
  • Description: describe the functionality of the item or process

Failure Modes

  • Type: set to "Failure Mode" value
  • Description: describe the failure
  • Potential Effects: describe potential impact of the failure on the system or users
  • SEV: rate severity of potential effects as a number from 1 (least severe) to 10 (most severe)

Potential Cause

  • Type: set to "Potential Cause" value
  • Description: describe the potential cause
  • SEV: rate severity of potential effects as a number from 1 (least severe) to 10 (most severe)
  • PROB: rate probability of the cause as a number from 1 (least likely) to 10 (most likely)
  • Detection Mode: describe existing design controls detecting the cause or preventing the failure from occurring
  • DET: rate detectability of the cause as a number from1 (best detectable) to 10 (least detectable)

Corrective Actions

  • Type: set to "Corrective Action" value
  • Description: describe the action for reducing the occurrence of the cause or improving the detection
  • Potential Effects: describe potential impact of the failure on the system or users after the corrective action is applied
  • SEV: rate new severity of the failure effects as a number from 1 (least severe) to 10 (most severe)
  • Detection Mode: describe how the action improves design controls detecting the failure or preventing the failure from occurring
  • DET: rate new detectability of the failure as a number from 1 (best detectable) to 10 (least detectable)
  • Responsibility: name the responsible person
  • Target Date: plan the action

children.text: The application crashes due to a bug
children.detection: Stability test of the application with corner case data.

children.text: Implement Autosave functionality storing immediately all changes into a persistent application storage so that only the last unsaved change is lost.

children.detection: Unit tests of user data handling with 90% coverage.
